messageBody:
On 10/31/05, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:

>
> If you can't see a use for a door now, why do you expect you'll find one
> later?


I don't, but others might. And they often do.

And I have sometimes be on the receiving end of such a feature: using a
protected method of a library that just happened to be there, then notified
the author of the library I was using it this way, and he said "I had never
thought of that, that's pretty cool, I'm going to make this hook officially
supported from now on".

You seem to be putting the cart before the horse. I design APIs
> to fit the use cases, not hypothesize use cases to justify an API.


In that case, chances are pretty good that a lot people gave up on your
libraries and you never knew because they never bothered to let you know.
And it's also likely that you considerably restricted the reach of your work
by artificially restricting it like this.

--
Cédric
